text:
Mobile Responsiveness is your 3rd feature to pass the course. So that is really up to you to own.

If it were me, I would look at:
• Most common screen resolutions
• Most common breakpoints
• Use Dev Tools and look at those sizes and how our application looks currently
• Adjust CSS to fix any display issues

text:
I coded a thing for displaying the movie log where you see a star rating with the rating you’ve given the movie, then you can click on a star to change that rating. It looks like this currently. (I copied/pasted formatting from Merve’s watchlist code so everything would look consistent. Also, I’m eventually going to fix that ‘date added’ field to make it look nicer. This is displaying with fake/placeholder data since I haven’t coded the ‘add’ option yet.)

I’m trying to figure out what the functionality to add movies to the log should look like. I can think of two options at this point:

Option 1:
Display a ‘log and rate’ button under each movie on the watchlist (displayed on the profile page)
This either automatically removes the movie from the watchlist or the window that pops up letting you rate the movie also lets you check a box to remove it from the watchlist
This is the only way to add movies to the log
This would make sense if we’re just thinking about the log as a way to track what movies you’ve found on the app then watched

Option 2:
In addition to the above, display a ‘log and rate’ button with movies appearing on search results/found through autocomplete search
This would make sense if we’re thinking about the log as a way to track all your movie viewing, not just viewing of movies you’ve first put on your watchlist

I’m leaning toward option 1 so we can keep the scope of the project a bit smaller, but I think both would be doable. What do you all think? Or are there other possibilities that I’m not thinking of?

I’m trying to figure out what the functionality to add movies to the log should look like. I can think of two options at this point:

Option 1:
Display a ‘log and rate’ button under each movie on the watchlist (displayed on the profile page)
This either automatically removes the movie from the watchlist or the window that pops up letting you rate the movie also lets you check a box to remove it from the watchlist
This is the only way to add movies to the log
This would make sense if we’re just thinking about the log as a way to track what movies you’ve found on the app then watched

Option 2:
In addition to the above, display a ‘log and rate’ button with movies appearing on search results/found through autocomplete search
This would make sense if we’re thinking about the log as a way to track all your movie viewing, not just viewing of movies you’ve first put on your watchlist

I’m leaning toward option 1 so we can keep the scope of the project a bit smaller, but I think both would be doable. What do you all think? Or are there other possibilities that I’m not thinking of?

text:
I echo what Eric said. I would get option one in place and then if you find yourself twiddling your thumbs (unlikely), you could tackle option two.

Otherwise you can always put that in place after the demo since it probably won’t be hard to your point and it’s something else you can showcase to a future employer.

text:
<@U057C75RYBB> 
*TLDR:* I am stuck and need help with props and the WatchListButton. I need fresh eyes from someone who
1. understands props much better than me, and
2. who wrote MovieDisplay and the function in the first place.

Happy to chat out loud when you get a chance to dig into this.
__________

*Long explanation:*
I am officially stuck on the WatchListButton and how to pass the props between all of the pages. And I think this is going to hold Merve up on ProfilePage as well.

The issue I am having is related to that there are key differences in what information about the movie is displayed and therefore available(?) between pages and it seems to make passing the right data as props very important between all of them. And I must just not be doing it right.
• On the profile page for the Watchlist display, we are only showing the movie title, movie poster, director, description/overview. 
• On the search and single movie pages (both which are rendered from the MovieDisplayComponent), we are displaying more information: the movie title, movie poster, director, description/overview, and in addition: the topCast, release_date, vote_average, service.provider_name; 
    ◦ *This is the same information that is saved into the Watchlist and therefore, we must pass it as props to WatchListButton from any page we display the button for handleWatchList to work*
• And finally, on the LandingPage, we are displaying the movie title, movie poster,  release_date, vote_average, different from both of the above. 
• And the issue I am coming across with how both LandingPage and ProfilePage work with the handleWatchlist function is that they throw undefined errors for the data they aren't displaying. 
    ◦ So the LandingPage throws undefined errors for director and topCast
    ◦ and the last time I tested, the ProfilePage threw undefined errors for release_date and topCast
I had stopped working on ProfilePage as I didn't want to take any logic work away from Merve so you won't see the ProfilePage in work in my latest branch, but in working on LandingPage, I am coming against the same issues and realizing it was likely an issue with my code and how I'm passing props.

I have updated props across *MovieDisplay, LandingPage and WatchListButton* the way I thought they needed to be to pass relevant data for the handleWatchlist function to work, but it's still not working/still getting the same *error on the LandingPage.* I am closer, and I thought I had it, but then I realized it wasn't actually working. <https://github.com/erinmuzughi/couchCats/tree/small-frontend-improvements|Here is my latest branch>.

text: In my opinion, this will be sufficient for MVP purposes. But the fact that you know about this issue and have done your due diligence with the research and know how to solve this problem on the next iteration of your project is something that an employer would love to hear. Make sure when presenting the project that you highlight this every time because it shows your competence. I would not do anything at this time, for the purpose of meeting MVP requirements, do anything that has a cost. Now if you and the group have finished all of your features and yall have the time to continue to the next iteration of the project, then by all means, go ahead and fix it. If not, time now should be dedicated to making sure that all team members have completed the features proposed.

text: Erin, this could be totally off base but is it possible this is an issue with how this data is labeled in the front end vs. back end? the data being returned by the back end has year and cast instead of release_date and top_cast. so if profile is accessing the data by calling the back end API to get the watchlist it isn’t going to recognize the release_date or top_cast fields. idk if there’s an easy way to standardize those labels because I don’t know the front end code that well but that’s my guess for what the issue is

elements.text: Erin, this could be totally off base but is it possible this is an issue with how this data is labeled in the front end vs. back end? the data being returned by the back end has year and cast instead of release_date and top_cast. so if profile is accessing the data by calling the back end API to get the watchlist it isn’t going to recognize the release_date or top_cast fields. idk if there’s an easy way to standardize those labels because I don’t know the front end code that well but that’s my guess for what the issue is

text: I'll look at it but to be honest, I think we should keep it off the front page for now. We should probably start polishing instead of adding. In hindsight, a lot of API calls should've been called from the backend and served to the front so that type of problem wasn't an issue. Does the button work everywhere else?

elements.text: I'll look at it but to be honest, I think we should keep it off the front page for now. We should probably start polishing instead of adding. In hindsight, a lot of API calls should've been called from the backend and served to the front so that type of problem wasn't an issue. Does the button work everywhere else?

text: The POST request was formatted that way because the cast call is very large (has everybody in production). The SQL database is setup to take VARCHAR and the director and cast variables are in a JSON format. That code allows it to be just a string.

elements.text: The POST request was formatted that way because the cast call is very large (has everybody in production). The SQL database is setup to take VARCHAR and the director and cast variables are in a JSON format. That code allows it to be just a string.
